instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01949: What is 820-01949? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
Customer claims there was liquid damage but only very minor corrosion was found by <CAPACITOR>C6454</CAPACITOR> . This turns on and works but refuses to charge the battery.

Replaced battery with a known good battery but no change

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.60 with or without battery.

What to check next??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
If <TRANSISTOR>Q6955</TRANSISTOR> is on the board, change it.
If not, change <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> is now 0v but no change.

Osx recognizes the battery but will not charge it or run off it. Service recommended message shows even on known good battery. Tried PRAM reset as well

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
Really known good battery, or new chinese supposed to be good?
What's the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> voltage with battery alone (no charger)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
Really known good apple original battery. No sticker with apple printing like other chinese suppose to be good.

0.850v <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 0.185v  <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> with battery only connected?
Be sure to have good contacts for J6951 and battery screw tight.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
After finding <RESISTOR>R7062</RESISTOR> was blown, replaced and  battery is now charging normally and runs off the battery no problem.

Stuck with the service recommended message though. Reloaded with Monterey but no change. Also tried SMC reset and PRAM reset.

What else can I try to remove the message? The same message appears with 3 different batteries on this board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
According to coconut battery the status is good and 100% capacity.

Ran into this issue another time with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Ended up fixing it by trying a new bios.

In this case would T2 need to be restored to be considered new bios? Tried revive option but no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01949</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wont charge battery
threads.message:
Many people complained on Internet about battery problem caused by Big Sur, or Monterey upgrade.
Save the data, do restore and reinstall original macOS.
